captions.text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

WES SILER: This is
the Yamaha R6.

This is the brand new
Aprilia Tuono V4R.

That's the guy named Jamie
who used to race
at the Isle of Man.
We're at Idlewild tonight.
Welcome to Rideapart.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

WES SILER: So this has been
around unchanged since 2005.
It's a Yamaha R6.
Is it good?

JAMIE ROBINSON: It's
amazingly good.

It does everything you
want it to do--

stops, corners, accelerates,
makes big bikes look slow.
WES SILER: It does do that.
JAMIE ROBINSON: It does.

Honestly, the feedback that the
bike gives you all of the

time is just so confidence
inspiring.
It's just a joy to ride.

It might look smaller than
yours, but it packs quite a
punch, man.

WES SILER: It's still a really,
really, really fast
motorcycle.

You're faster on this little 600
with 125 horsepower than I

am on this liter bike
with 162 horsepower.
JAMIE ROBINSON: Yeah.
[OVERLAPPING VOICES]

JAMIE ROBINSON: It corners
like it's on rails.

WES SILER: Yeah, it
looks like it.
You look great, I mean.
JAMIE ROBINSON: Yeah.

Well, you know, it's
been said before.

WES SILER: I'm riding the
new Aprilia Tuono V4R.

It's physically the same size
as this motorcycle, but this
is a 1,000-cc V4.
So that's 600-cc inline four.
That has 120 horsepower.
This has 162.

And they both set out to
do the same thing.

You know, they're both fast
motorcycles for riding

enthusiastically, which is
what we're doing today.

Having said that, you know,
I've got more power.

I've got traction control,
wheelie control, launch
control, quick shifts.

I think it might be me,
but I'm a little
slower than you are.

JAMIE ROBINSON: Wheelie
control?
[INTERPOSING VOICES]
WES SILER: Well, I need it.

JAMIE ROBINSON: It's called
your right wrist isn't it?

WES SILER: I used my traction
control though.
You saw that.

JAMIE ROBINSON: I tell you what,
I didn't know you could

get traction control on this
little tire, but--
[MUSIC PLAYING]

JAMIE ROBINSON: The R6, it's
just doing, their Supersport

600, they're all the
same pretty much.

They all have excellent brakes,
excellent suspension.

And, you know, they're just so
nimble that you're able to

just do what you want
to do with them.

And it's very hard then to
expect, you know, to look at

another motorcycle and expect
it's going to be better.
It's a great package.
It's almost perfect.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

WES SILER: The Tuono
is more, right.
It's a bigger engine.
It's more power.
It's more torque.
It's more electronics.
It's flashier.
It's more money.
JAMIE ROBINSON: Yeah.

WES SILER: And what I get out
of that, obviously it's not
related to the performance.

You can't really go faster on
the street than you can go on
the Supersport 600.

What I get is I get a different
experience.

I get a more visceral,
challenging experience than a
regular 600.
JAMIE ROBINSON: Yeah.

WES SILER: Because that
Tuono is a monster.

JAMIE ROBINSON: I could
see it, you know.

And also you're working
quite hard on it.

And I'm behind you just, you
know, twiddling my thumbs.

The 600 is so light
and nimble.

I'm not thinking about
the corners.

And I can see you making effort
to get into there.

WES SILER: Throwing
my body weight.
[INTERPOSING VOICES]

JAMIE ROBINSON: But, man, when
you touch that throttle that
just takes off.
There's a lot of power.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

WES SILER: Well, what I really
like about motorcycles, I like
going fast.

And we are on two of the fastest
motorcycles ever made.

It is an exciting
fun day for us.

It's a weird situation because
while they are the most fun I

think you can have on
a bike, they're also
what gets us in trouble.

You know, that's what people
don't like about sport bikes.
They're loud.
Sport bikes go fast.
Sports bikes are scary.

People kill themselves
with sports bikes.

And so it's a weird situation,
you know, that we're in.

Where it's enjoyable
and it's fun.

We can be responsible while
still being a little
extra-legal.

But a lot of people don't act
responsibly on sports bikes,
which is a shame.

JAMIE ROBINSON: That's the thing
is we don't want to be
annoying anybody.

Because it just makes
motorcycles look bad.

And, you know, that's not
what it's all about.

WES SILER: And then people
don't want to ride them
because they hate us.
JAMIE ROBINSON: Exactly.

But at the same time, you know,
it's very easy just to

make our way by vehicles
when we're out here.

WES SILER: We can pass
quickly and safely.
JAMIE ROBINSON: Yeah.
Absolutely.
WES SILER: Plenty of vision.
You can move around--
JAMIE ROBINSON: That's the key.
Vision.
Is key.
WES SILER: Yeah.

JAMIE ROBINSON: You know,
being able to see around

another couple of corners allows
you to be able to do
that safely.
[MOTORCYCLE ENGINES SOUNDING]

WES SILER: I was told
you were a racer.

JAMIE ROBINSON: I'm
not allowed to?
WES SILER: Yes.
You're actually a builder.

JAMIE ROBINSON: My
dad's a builder.

WES SILER: I know you're
not a mover.
[LAUGHTER]

JAMIE ROBINSON: You
know that truth.
Where was I while you [BLEEP]
for me?

WES SILER: Swanning
about Europe.
JAMIE ROBINSON: I was.

WES SILER: So we're running some
pretty fast bikes today.
JAMIE ROBINSON: We are.

WES SILER: What happens
if we crash them?

JAMIE ROBINSON: Well,
we're lucky.
We're protected.
And that's essential.

If you're going to ride a
motorcycle, you've got to be
covered head to toe.

WES SILER: How fast have
you come off in
one of these suits?

JAMIE ROBINSON: My top speed
crash was Magellan, 160 into
the front straight.

WES SILER: And what
happened to you?

JAMIE ROBINSON: I didn't
break any bones.

I wasn't so well for a
little while there.
But--
[INTERPOSING VOICES]

JAMIE ROBINSON: I
just bounced.

Yeah, a major bit of concussion,
bashed around.

But, you know, managed to
walk away from that one.

And to think about it, you know,
you think about crashing
a motorcycle.

And you don't even have to take
a look a your leather

suit afterwards to just realize
how luck you were that

you were wearing something
protective.
And it's absolutely essential.

I think you've got
to be protected.

And it really just starts with
every little detail.

Hands, the first thing you put
down in a crash is your hands.

So you must be wearing
gloves and the one
piece leather suits.
It's the best you can get.

But when I see people in
shorts and t-shirts--
WES SILER: Oh, it kills me.
It kills me.
JAMIE ROBINSON: I just cringe.

And these people have obviously
never, ever crashed
a motorcycle.

WES SILER: Let's go
get some lunch.
JAMIE ROBINSON: I'd like that.
Last one there buys lunch.
WES SILER: Deal.
JAMIE ROBINSON: Oh, [BLEEP].
[BLEEP]
you.
WES SILER: Ow!
Ow!
[LAUGHTER]
[MUSIC PLAYING]

JAMIE ROBINSON: And that's
what motorcycles
is all about really.

It's got to put a smile
on your face.

And, you know, I know that
obviously the Aprilia is doing
that for you.

And the R6 is just doing
that for me.

As soon as I see you know, a
tight little corner, the

thing's just railing
around it.

And that put the biggest
grin on my face.

GRANT RAY: Would you actually
be interested in switching?

Or is it that you're so kind of
like, head over heels that

you want to stick with
what you've got?

WES SILER: I don't know about
Jaime, but I'm not switching.
I love that Aprilia.
I just love it.
It's evocative.
It's fast.
It sounds great.
It's fun.

And I'll be pretty comfortable
on the highway.

JAMIE ROBINSON: I
love Aprilias.
I love Italy.
But I'm sticking with my R6.

That thing is amazing
around corners.

And there's like 200 corners
out of here.
So I'm going to go play.
I'm keeping the R6.

WES SILER: I'm going to
show you [INAUDIBLE].
JAMIE ROBINSON: See ya.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

JAMIE ROBINSON: Can
we do that again?
That was the [BLEEP]
[BLEEP]
girly, balls out [BLEEP]
wheelie I've ever done.
Yes.

WES SILER: You're being
a weenie, Jamie.
JAMIE ROBINSON: Look, I know.

But, you know, the English like
to drive on the left.
It confuses me all the time.

WES SILER: Just one corner, just
got a little confused.
You're like, you know, aah.

JAMIE ROBINSON: The good news
is we're not on one of them.

WES SILER: They can't
be having any fun.

title: The Fine Art Of Canyon Carving - /RideApart

comments.text: This is art﻿
comments.author: bunnyDrug
Brian Yong

comments.text:
Don't be daft...nobody thinks Gsxr riders are reckless...here in the UK we 
carry around the McDonald's sauce packs to hand to Gsxr riders to go with 
their chicken strips:-P.



Nah just playing, your right it is an unfair stereotype, but because they 
are so obvious from any other bike and look so aggressive in body position 
and style, often people get the wrong impression! Ultimately I like sport 
bikes because they feel so smooth and make me feel like a little boy in a 
space ship haha! Each to their own
comments.author: david Kerridge

comments.text:
ignorant comment at the end about how the cruiser guys "can't be having any 
fun." Cruisers are a lot of fun! I ride a sport bike but If I had the money 
I would totally own a cruiser. They are fun in a different way, just as the 
Aprilia and Yamaha are fun in different ways.﻿

comments.author: 879doogie

comments.text: What video editing software do you all use? This is gorgeous!
comments.author: Adam Stoltzfus

comments.text: Aprilia is me second favorite brand of bikes.
comments.author: Chris Carter

comments.text:
i always have my gear on.my friends look at me funny when we ride because i 
have full body armor from head to toe and all they use is a helmet, gloves 
and boots.i had road rash once and that sh#t is so painful that i learned 
my lesson.
comments.author: 010steveo

comments.text: "extra-legal" LOL
comments.author: Mikhail Paremski

comments.text: The fine art is not doing it on the street, but rather on the track
comments.author: $$E$$

comments.text:
The R6 is an amazing race bike, great track day bike, but far from best 
street bike. I'd rather have the new Kawi 636, but there's still something 
about the R6 that makes you forget it's an eight year old design.
comments.author: turbo311

comments.text: So um, art of canyon carving............?
comments.author: turbo311

comments.text: LOL threw the key 7:09
comments.author: r0y02

comments.text:
The scrubbing. It hurts. Bad. And by the time they start to scrub, your 
adrenaline has already subsided. Imagine someone rubbing a cheese grater on 
an open wound. This was all because i was wearing full gear head to toe, 
but forgot to zip my pants to my jacket. They separated during a high side. 
My pants fell down. My jacket rode up. My skin was caressed ever so 
painfully by the chunky asphalt. Just wear your gear people. You have no 
idea what discomfort really is.
comments.author: Sam Iam

comments.text:
Quite honestly, no one should attempt to ride a motorcycle like these guys 
on a public highway! This aggressive stuff should really only be done on a 
track, and only by riders who are well-qualified to do it.
comments.author: Ed Zaslow

comments.text:
That's the point though, you haven't had a problem "yet." Someday something 
might happen and I would hope you will regret it. I'm fairly new to the 
rode but have been riding dirt bikes along with other off road vehicles all 
of my life and my gear has saved my life multiple times, even though I'm a 
fairly safe rider. Shit happens that you can't prepare for, that's why you 
wear gear so you don't get tore up too bad when it does happen.
comments.author: xMisterTryHard

comments.text:
chill out, I ride in a bright purple mesh tank top and jean short cut-offs 
and ive never had a problem.........
comments.author: 2bidfilmsguy

comments.text: You guys are great !
comments.author: RubberGently

comments.text:
I really appreciate this clip. I'm Italian and here traffic it's a bit of a 
mess and so are the roads. Ride safely must be the first thing but I also 
think that if everyone has some bike experience we would be much more safe 
(I hope my English is understandable)
comments.author: Giuseppe Granatiero

comments.text: Absolutely "ATGATT". Ride Safe!!!
comments.author: Thelby1

comments.text:
This video should be part of a RideApart "Canyon Carving Series." I've 
watched this video several times. More RideApart!

comments.text: Tuono is a big bike, counter-steer it man!
comments.author: Onare Danichs

comments.text:
How safe is safe? I always look in all directions when I'm riding in 
traffic ESPECIALLY behind me. I don't let people get to close to my ass and 
always more out of the way when they do. A lot of other guys I see aren't 
that careful.

comments.author: RanNero

comments.text: isnt this canyon by lake hemet and banning?
comments.author: hmoobmc

comments.text:
Agreed on gear, have never gone down and I ride a 2012 Triumph 675, I feel 
amazing knowing that if I go down, I have entry level race boots, textile 
pants with knee and hip armor, and a Alpinestar full leather jacket with 
back hum, elbow forearm shoulder and back protector. Can't forget Carbon 
fiber leather Astar gloves. I just feel good, allows me to be confident 
when I ride which only compliments my already reserved riding attitude. I 
do enjoy a spirited ride though. Cheers.
comments.author: Dub3God

comments.text: this two guys are so sweet...kind of little gay.hahaha
comments.author: Julian

comments.text:
Are you looking for an awesome helmet? Arai Corsair-V way better than Bell 
helmet.
comments.author: braz41nj

comments.text:
Though, Im NOT in for riders not having full protection, would just like to 
add that... "Riding safer" could also mean being spatially and 
situationally aware of those bimbos on their iPhones... "Riding safer" 
means being proactive not reactive...

comments.author: AIBETTSYIA75

comments.text: Someone owns a Harley
comments.author: fishknuckle100

comments.text: by lunch they mean buttsex in the woods. buncha tools
comments.author: Willy Wonka

comments.text:
well its either choose to ride without what people think is proper riding 
gear or not ride at all...i guess im choosing with ride without...and for 
the ones saying i havent been in a wreck then you dont know me...my $25k in 
medical bills and knee surgery will attest to that...problem is there isnt 
sufficient gear for big people
comments.author: MidwestVlogger

comments.text:
LOL, the biggest culprit to trolling are people like yourself, instigating 
on the comment section with your self righteous bullshit. Boo hoo if you 
grinded your elbow to the bone, it wasn't my fault nor any one else but 
your damn self. Instead of nit picking the community that doesn't exactly 
follow your new found love of one piece leathers and full gauntlet gloves, 
why don't you just worry about your own skin and stop being a pest or on 
the internet, a troll.
comments.author: HypermaxZ

comments.text:
I do, I've also slid down the pavement at 60 mph with insufficient gear on 
and ground my right elbow to the bone. If you're going to troll at least 
put some effort into it.
comments.author: Thomas Gionet

comments.text:
I take it you don't even own a motorcycle license, just like all the other 
condescending pussies on the gear nazi crusade.
comments.author: HypermaxZ

comments.text: I take it you haven't crashed yet
comments.author: Thomas Gionet
